body:
I would like to look into this.

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/ad82a2792b792c6357c8c0db815772bae04c86c1/sktime/forecasting/base/adapters/_pmdarima.py#L124

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/ad82a2792b792c6357c8c0db815772bae04c86c1/sktime/forecasting/base/adapters/_pmdarima.py#L136-L138

Was thinking about this the other day!
Same for AutoETS, it should return the Error Trend and Seasonal components of the chosen model e.g. AAA, ANN etc.
@ltsaprounis, do you know whether AutoETS is following the same interface (in which case we should extend this issue's scope) or not (in which case we should open a new "good first issue")?

Yes there is a get_fitted_params function in the statsmodels adapter, but for now it returns nothing for AutoETS.  https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/ad82a2792b792c6357c8c0db815772bae04c86c1/sktime/forecasting/base/adapters/_statsmodels.py#L87

I discovered that when working on #942. I think get_fitted_params should return the fitted parameters (level, smoothing parameters etc.) for ExponentialSmoothing and for AutoETS it should return those plus the selected model. Same behaviour should be expected for ARIMA and AutoARIMA.
I would like to work on this issue.

@BINAYKUMAR943, @afzal442, have you been working on this?
Generally, the issue is yours (for a while) once you say
Thanks @fkiraly , does that mean how to retrieve `pdq` from `max_p, max_d, max_q`? I am not sure but that I understood.

@fkiraly sorry, it's my bad!. I missed this. 

> @BINAYKUMAR943, @afzal442, have you been working on this?
> Generally, the issue is yours (for a while) once you say

I didn't know that. I was waiting it to be assigned. I am currently working on some issues in the classification module.

>Thanks @fkiraly , does that mean how to retrieve pdq from max_p, max_d, max_q? I am not sure but that I understood.

Precisely!

>I didn't know that. I was waiting it to be assigned. I am currently working on some issues in the classification module.

Ah - sorry, should have made this clearer.
